title: How to Replace a Bathroom Faucet Handle

steps.title: Turn off the water supply to the faucet.
steps.content: Turn off the water supply to the faucet. Look beneath the sink for a valve close to the wall on the same side as the handle you are replacing. If this is a single handle faucet, turn off both supplies. When you locate them, twist the water supply valve or valves tightly to the right. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Test the faucet to ensure no water comes out when the handle to be replaced is turned.
steps.content: Test the faucet to ensure no water comes out when the handle to be replaced is turned.

steps.title: Examine the cap or top of the handle.
steps.content: Examine the cap or top of the handle. Typically faucet handles have a false top or cap. This may be a porcelain cap that reads "hot" or "cold," or it may be a metal cap in the same finish as the rest of the handle.

steps.title: Use a flat head screwdriver to loosen the cap and pry it up.
steps.content: Use a flat head screwdriver to loosen the cap and pry it up. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the area hidden beneath the cap for a screw.
steps.content: Look at the area hidden beneath the cap for a screw.

steps.title: Use the appropriate screwdriver to loosen and remove this screw.
steps.content: Use the appropriate screwdriver to loosen and remove this screw. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Lift off the handle of the faucet from its stem.
steps.content: Lift off the handle of the faucet from its stem.

steps.title: Look at the back of the escutcheon or decorative cover at the bottom of the handle.
steps.content: Look at the back of the escutcheon or decorative cover at the bottom of the handle. There should be a very small hole with an Allen key screw in the back.

steps.title: Use an Allen key to loosen and remove this screw.
steps.content: Use an Allen key to loosen and remove this screw.

steps.title: Lift the escutcheon off of the counter.
steps.content: Lift the escutcheon off of the counter. The interior valve of the faucet should now be visible.

steps.title: Place a new escutcheon over the valve.
steps.content: Place a new escutcheon over the valve.

steps.title: Line up the screw at the back and tighten it down so the escutcheon does not move.
steps.content: Line up the screw at the back and tighten it down so the escutcheon does not move.

steps.title: Place the handle over the top of the valve so it sits on the escutcheon.
steps.content: Place the handle over the top of the valve so it sits on the escutcheon.

steps.title: Twist it completely to the "on" position and back off to make sure it is positioned properly.
steps.content: Twist it completely to the "on" position and back off to make sure it is positioned properly.

steps.title: Insert a screw into the top of the handle and tighten it down.
steps.content: Insert a screw into the top of the handle and tighten it down. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place the cover or cap into the top of the handle.
steps.content: Place the cover or cap into the top of the handle. If the cap reads "hot", "color" or another word, line this up to face you.

steps.title: Snap the cap down into the cap of the faucet.
steps.content: Snap the cap down into the cap of the faucet.

steps.title: Turn on the water supply and test the handle.
steps.content: Turn on the water supply and test the handle.
